The ball was o'er: — gay Fashion's weary train,</br>Well pleased, their homes and drowsy beds regain.</br>Ellen and Jane, whom two fond sparks admire,</br>To their joint couch with fluttering hearts retire;</br>But ere, in sleep, their heavy eyelids close,</br>Thus scan the merits of their favourite beaux.

ELLEN.</br>My Henry's foot is formed in beauty's mould;</br>Small, slender, straight, delightful to behold.</br>His silken hose and glossy shoe so neat</br>Should Turkey carpets tread, and not the street.
JANE.</br>My William's hand is like a lady's, small,</br>White as the snowy flakes that gently fall;</br>Softer than silk; and, oh!  ye powers divine!</br>How sweetly thrilling, when it touches mine!

ELLEN.</br>Parted before is Henry's glossy hair;</br>Combed and Macassar'd with the nicest care,</br>When he emerges from his tailor's hands,</br>Padded and stuff'd as elegance demands,</br>And tightly laced in Cantellotic stays,</br>A form more true no slender wasp betrays.

JANE.</br>Fine flaxen curls adore my William's head;</br>His cheek presents the purest white and red;</br>His dimpled features wear a constant smile;</br>His soft blue eyes to melting love beguile;</br>His shape, his air, his gait, all, all conspire,</br>To make him just the darling I admire.
ELLEN.</br>In finest linen is my Henry seen,</br>White as the snow, and every morning clean:</br>Like paper stiff, the well starched collars rise,</br>Embrace his ears, and mount above his eyes.
JANE.</br>My William's collar does his chin enclose,</br>And shoots six inches forward of his nose,</br>I know he changes collars twice a day;</br>But that he wears a shirt, I cannot say.

ELLEN.</br>Some beaux wear cravats red, and some wear blue;</br>My Henry's cravat is of emerald hue.</br>When thus attired, he to my view displays</br>A stiff neck bandaged with good warm green baize.

JANE.</br>Red, blue, or green, let other dandies buy;</br>My William's cravat is of yellow die.</br>When first I viewed him in that neckcloth drest,</br>I laughed outright, and thus the beau addrest:</br>"Hast thou purloined, to cure a swollen throat,</br>Thy mother's yellow flannel petticoat?"

ELLEN.</br>My Henry smokes tobacco, — snuffs and chews;</br>With Otto and Cologne his dress imbues;</br>Drenches with lavender his kerchief white,</br>And squanders every perfume of delight;</br>Till from the man united scents exhale,</br>Rich as the ripeness of a rabit's tail.</br>Not more refreshing are the gusts that pop</br>From the oped door of Pestle's physic shop;</br>Or the blest odours, that elastic stray</br>From blended musk and assafoetida.

JANE.</br>William sips punch, of Irish whiskey made,</br>Or that compound of rum and lemonade;</br>Orri, famed root, (not vile tobacco) chews,</br>And with its sweets his balmy breath imbues.</br>Let poets feign, or voyagers attest,</br>The spicy gales of Araby the blest;</br>Let the brown maids, whose hands, inured to toil,</br>Rear savoury bulbs in Weathersfield's rich soil,</br>Boast that no perfume, Asia yields us, matches</br>The redolescence of their onion patches.</br>Not blest Arabia's aromatic gales,</br>Not the strong odours which the leek exhales,</br>Are half so rich in redolence divine,</br>As Williams orris'd lips, when pressed to mine.

A shoeless step now shakes the sounding floor!</br>The father's knuckle strikes the sounding door:</br>"Hush, girls!" — he cries; — "no more these vigils keep;</br>But hold your noisy tongues, and go to sleep."</br>
